questionText: An 88-year-old man has a high grade subarachnoid hemorrhage due to a ruptured right MCA bifurcation aneurysm, which was emergently coiled. On Day 5 he develops subtle left upper extremity drift. You review his quantitative EEG, specifically the alpha/delta ratios (Fig. 8Q1).

options.text: Alpha/delta ratios are higher in the right hemisphere because of decreased CBF and delayed cerebral ischemia on the right.
Alpha/delta ratios are higher in the right hemisphere because of ongoing seizure in the right hemisphere.
Alpha/delta ratios are lower in the right hemisphere because of decreased CBF and delayed cerebral ischemia on the right.
Alpha/delta ratios are higher in the left hemisphere because of ongoing seizure in the left hemisphere.

explanation: Delayed cerebral ischemia causes a drop in alpha and a rise in delta activity, so the alpha/delta ratio falls in the ischemic (right) hemisphere.

questionText: A 47-year-old woman with remote right frontal stroke is comatose off sedation. A 45-minute epoch of her quantitative EEG is shown (Fig. 8Q2) with a green bracket, arrow, and box. These markings most likely represent:
explanation: The bracket marks frequent bilateral high-amplitude seizures (NCSE), the arrow a midazolam bolus/infusion causing suppression, and the box a breakthrough seizure, indicating the need to increase the infusion.

questionText: A 29-year-old man suffers an out-of-hospital cardiac arrest with 15 min to ROSC. Off sedation he remains comatose with only brainstem reflexes. Continuous EEG shows a compressed 20 s sample (timebase 15 mm/s) (Fig. 8Q3).

options.text: This pattern predicts a good neurological recovery.
This is an isoelectric EEG confirming brain death.
This pattern is consistent with burst suppression.

explanation: Alternating low-amplitude bursts and suppression periods (1â€“2 s bursts, high suppression ratio) define burst suppression, which after cardiac arrest off sedation portends a very poor prognosis.
